Description: Limestone statuette of a ram-headed figure sitting on a throne supported by rams, possibly a depiction of Zeus-Ammon or Baal Hammon; the figure is dressed in an Ionian-style chiton.
Curator's comments: Thrones with ram supports are common in the late CA to early Hellenistic periods (Coenaerts and Samaes 2006, with further references; also Buchholz 1991 passim). These usually support an image of the horned god (variously interpreted as Baal-Hammon, Zeus-Hammon or a Cypriot deity using the iconography of these foreign deities (Sophocleous 1985,.58-69; Buchholz 1991; Counts 2008; Kleibel 2007). Buchholz mistakenly attributed the item to the Lang collection, though it may well have originated there (perhaps as a gift to Cesnola from Lang) if the Dali provenance given by Myres (ABSA 41, 1940-45, 64) is correct, though this is uncertain. Bibliography: Buchholz H.-G. 1991, Der Gott Hammon und Zeus Hammon auf Zypern, AM 106, 85-108. Coenaerts J. and Samaes M. 2006, 'The ram throne: A true type of Cypriote furniture?', RDAC, 239-58. Counts D. 2008, 'From Siwa to Cyprus: The assimilation of Zeus Ammon in the Cypriote pantheon', in eds D. Michaelides et al., Egypt and Cyprus in Antiquity (Oxford and Oakville), 104-17. Kleibel K. 2007, 'The background of the Cypriot Ram God's iconography', in eds S. Christodoulou and A. Satraki, POCA 2007: Postgraduate Cypriot Archaeology Conference (Newcastle), 145-68. Sophocleous S. 1985, Atlas des représentations Cypro-Archaïques des divinités. SIMA Pocket-Book 33 (Göteborg).
